cards.name: Metallic Sliver
cards.flavorText: When the clever counterfeit was accepted by the hive, Volrath's influence upon the slivers grew even stronger.

rulings.text: If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.

cards.name: Virulent Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have poisonous 1. (Whenever a Sliver deals combat damage to a player, that player gets a poison counter. A player with ten or more poison counters loses the game.)

rulings.text: If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.
A player with ten or more poison counters loses the game as a state-based action, even if no permanents with poisonous are on the battlefield.
If a creature has multiple instances of poisonous, each triggers separately.
Poisonous 1 causes the player to get just one poison counter when a Sliver deals combat damage to them, no matter how much damage that Sliver dealt.

cards.name: Amoeboid Changeling
cards.text:
Changeling (This card is every creature type.)
{T}: Target creature gains all creature types until end of turn.
{T}: Target creature loses all creature types until end of turn.

rulings.text: If a creature loses all creature types but then gains a new creature type later in the turn, it will be that new creature type.

cards.name: Winged Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have flying.
cards.flavorText:
"Everything around here has cut a deal with gravity."
—Gerrard of the *Weatherlight*

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.name: Clot Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have "{2}: Regenerate this permanent."
cards.flavorText:
"One would think I would be accustomed to unexpected returns."
—Hanna, *Weatherlight* navigator

cards.name: Frenzy Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have frenzy 1. (Whenever a Sliver attacks and isn't blocked, it gets +1/+0 until end of turn.)
cards.flavorText: The Arturan conjurers took the strange, alien fossil and patterned their own twisted creations in its image.

rulings.text: An ability that triggers when something “attacks and isn’t blocked” triggers in the declare blockers step after blockers are declared if (1) that creature is attacking and (2) no creatures are declared to block it. It will trigger even if that creature was put onto the battlefield attacking rather than having been declared as an attacker in the declare attackers step.

cards.flavorText: Gerrard looked all around for the source of the mysterious pulse, and at that moment the slivers boiled forth from the crevasses.

cards.flavorText:

cards.flavorText: The air was filled with the cracks and snaps of flesh hardening as the new sliver joined the battle.

rulings.text: Yes, it does give the +1/+1 bonus to itself.

cards.name: Quick Sliver
cards.text:
Flash
Any player may cast Sliver spells as though they had flash.
cards.flavorText: The directors of the Riptide Project wanted instant results on the sliver experiments. They got their wish.

rulings.text: The first ability applies when this card is not on the battlefield. The second ability applies when this card is on the battlefield.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.

cards.name: Crystalline Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have shroud. (They can't be the targets of spells or abilities.)
cards.flavorText: Bred as living shields, these slivers have proven unruly—they know they cannot be caught.

rulings.text: The ability only applies while this card is on the battlefield.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.

cards.text: All Slivers have "{2}, Sacrifice this permanent: This permanent deals 2 damage to any target."
cards.flavorText: The first sliver burst against the cave wall, and others piled in behind to deepen the new tunnel.

cards.name: Spined Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver becomes blocked, that Sliver gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each creature blocking it.
cards.flavorText:
"Slivers are evil and slivers are sly; And if you get eaten, then no one will cry."
—Mogg children's rhyme

rulings.text: If two Spined Slivers are on the battlefield then each blocked sliver gets +2/+2 for each creature blocking it.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.name: Victual Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have "{2}, Sacrifice this permanent: You gain 4 life."
cards.flavorText: "We are kinfolk," explained Karn to the sliver queen. "Just as you need your progeny to complete you, so do I need the pieces of the Legacy to make me whole."

cards.flavorText:
Hanna: "We must learn how they protect each other."
Mirri: "After they've done trying to kill us, all right?"

cards.text: All Sliver creatures have "{2}: This creature gets +1/+1 until end of turn."
cards.flavorText:
"Sure, I've seen agents of the Cabal here and there. Well, not here, and certainly not in any of the sliver labs. Oh dear, I've said too much."
—Apprentice researcher

cards.name: Barbed Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have "{2}: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn."
cards.flavorText: Spans of spines leapt from one sliver to the next, forming a deadly hedge around the *Weatherlight*.

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.

cards.name: Homing Sliver
cards.text:
Each Sliver card in each player's hand has slivercycling {3}.
Slivercycling {3} ({3}, Discard this card: Search your library for a Sliver card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle.)

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.
Unlike a normal cycling ability, Slivercycling doesn’t have you draw a card. Instead, it lets you search your library for a Sliver card.

Slivercycling is a form of cycling. Any ability that triggers on a card being cycled also triggers on Slivercycling a card. Any ability that stops a cycling ability from being activated also stops Slivercycling from being activated.

cards.name: Necrotic Sliver
cards.text: All Slivers have "{3}, Sacrifice this permanent: Destroy target permanent."
cards.flavorText: Though Volrath is long dead, the slivers have become everything he wanted them to be: mindless instruments of destruction and despair.

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn't provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it's no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.name: Fungus Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have "Whenever this creature is dealt damage, put a +1/+1 counter on it." (It must survive the damage to get the counter.)
cards.flavorText:
"When a sliver of this breed enters the hive, the others claw each other in frenzied fits, thereby ensuring their rapid growth."
—Rukarumel, field journal

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.
If multiple sources deal damage to a Sliver at the same time and that Sliver survives the damage, it gets only one +1/+1 counter despite its impressive efforts.

cards.name: Brood Sliver
cards.text: Whenever a Sliver deals combat damage to a player, its controller may create a 1/1 colorless Sliver creature token.
cards.flavorText: Within weeks, more slivers nested in Otaria than ever existed on Rath.

rulings.text: This card’s controller controls the triggered ability, but the controller of the Sliver that deals damage to a player decides whether or not to put the token onto the battlefield under their control.

Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

cards.name: Might Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures get +2/+2.
cards.flavorText:
"The colossal thing rumbled over the ridge, tree husks crumbling before it. The ones we were already fighting howled as it came, their muscles suddenly surging, and we knew it was time to flee."
—Llanach, Skyshroud ranger

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.
Because damage remains marked on a creature until the damage is removed as the turn ends, nonlethal damage dealt to a Sliver may become lethal if Might Sliver leaves the battlefield during that turn.

cards.name: Sliver Overlord
cards.text:
{3}: Search your library for a Sliver card, reveal that card, put it into your hand, then shuffle.
{3}: Gain control of target Sliver. (This effect lasts indefinitely.)
cards.flavorText: The end of evolution.

cards.name: Fury Sliver
cards.text: All Sliver creatures have double strike.
cards.flavorText:
"A rift opened, and our arrows were abruptly stilled. To move was to push the world. But the sliver's claw still twitched, red wounds appeared in Thed's chest, and ribbons of blood hung in the air."
—Adom Capashen, Benalish hero

rulings.text: Abilities that Slivers grant, as well as power/toughness boosts, are cumulative. However, for some abilities, like flying, having more than one instance of the ability doesn’t provide any additional benefit.
If the creature type of a Sliver changes so it’s no longer a Sliver, it will no longer be affected by its own ability. Its ability will continue to affect other Sliver creatures.

If a creature loses double strike after assigning damage in the first strike combat damage step (due to Fury Sliver leaving the battlefield, for example), that creature won’t assign damage in the normal combat damage step.

cards.name: Heartstone
cards.text: Activated abilities of creatures cost {1} less to activate. This effect can't reduce the mana in that cost to less than one mana.
cards.flavorText:
"Finding a true heartstone is even harder than finding a true heart."
—Hanna, *Weatherlight* navigator

rulings.text: The cost reduction can be applied to additional costs.
It will not add a {1} to abilities with no generic mana in their activation cost.
It will never reduce any colored mana portion of an activation cost.
Can’t reduce Snow mana costs.
Activated abilities contain a colon. They’re generally written “[Cost]: [Effect].” Some keywords are activated abilities and will have colons in their reminder text.

cards.name: Distant Melody
cards.text: Choose a creature type. Draw a card for each permanent you control of that type.
cards.flavorText: Oona's song is like a twisted dinner chime. All the faeries return home, but it is Oona who feasts—on the stolen dreams and rumors they serve her.

rulings.text: Note that this spell counts the number of permanents you control of the chosen type, not just the number of creatures you control. It will also take your tribal permanents into account.

cards.name: Aphetto Dredging
cards.text: Return up to three target creature cards of the creature type of your choice from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavorText: Phage became both executioner and savior, helping others to the same rebirth she had found.

rulings.text: You need to choose the creature type before choosing the targets.

cards.name: Coat of Arms
cards.text: Each creature gets +1/+1 for each other creature on the battlefield that shares at least one creature type with it. (For example, if two Goblin Warriors and a Goblin Shaman are on the battlefield, each gets +2/+2.)
cards.flavorText:
"Hup, two, three, four,
Dunno how to count no more."
—Mogg march

rulings.text: If a creature has more than one creature type, and one of those types matches the creature you are calculating for, then count that creature. Only one type needs to match in order to get counted.
If you have a creature with more than one creature type, count all creatures which have either creature type.
Sharing multiple creature types doesn’t give an additional bonus. Coat of Arms counts creatures, not creature types.

cards.name: Wild Pair
cards.text: Whenever a creature enters the battlefield, if you cast it from your hand, you may search your library for a creature card with the same total power and toughness, put it onto the battlefield, then shuffle.

rulings.text: If you cast a 2/2 Grizzly Bears, for example, you may then search for any creature with total power and toughness 4. It can be 0/4, 1/3, 2/2, or 3/1.

The game checks the power and toughness of the creature that just entered the battlefield as it exists on the battlefield. That might mean it’s impossible to get another copy of that same card. For example, a Triskelion on the battlefield is 4/4, but a Triskelion in your library is 1/1. The power and toughness might also have been affected while the triggered ability was on the stack (such as with Giant Growth, Sudden Death, or Ovinize).

If the creature that entered the battlefield has left the battlefield by the time the ability resolves, use the power and toughness of that creature as it last appeared before leaving the battlefield.

cards.name: Ancient Ziggurat
cards.text: {T}: Add one mana of any color. Spend this mana only to cast a creature spell.
cards.flavorText: Built in honor of Alara's creatures, the ziggurat vanished long ago. When Progenitus awakened, the temple emerged again.

rulings.text: Mana produced by Ancient Ziggurat can be spent on any part of a creature spell’s total cost. This includes additional costs (such as kicker) and alternative costs (such as evoke or Worldheart Phoenix’s alternative cost).
Mana produced by Ancient Ziggurat can’t be spent on activated abilities that put a creature card directly onto the battlefield, such as unearth or ninjutsu.

cards.name: Rootbound Crag
cards.text:
Rootbound Crag enters the battlefield tapped unless you control a Mountain or a Forest.
{T}: Add {R} or {G}.

rulings.text: This checks for lands you control with the land type Mountain or Forest, not for lands named Mountain or Forest. The lands it checks for don’t have to be basic lands. For example, if you control Temple Garden (a nonbasic land with the land types Forest and Plains), Rootbound Crag will enter the battlefield untapped.
As this is entering the battlefield, it checks for lands that are already on the battlefield. It won’t see lands that are entering the battlefield at the same time (due to Warp World, for example).

cards.name: Rupture Spire
cards.text:
Rupture Spire enters the battlefield tapped.
When Rupture Spire enters the battlefield, sacrifice it unless you pay {1}.
{T}: Add one mana of any color.

cards.name: Terramorphic Expanse
cards.text: {T}, Sacrifice Terramorphic Expanse: Search your library for a basic land card, put it onto the battlefield tapped, then shuffle.

cards.name: Vivid Creek
cards.text:
Vivid Creek enters the battlefield tapped with two charge counters on it.
{T}: Add {U}.
{T}, Remove a charge counter from Vivid Creek: Add one mana of any color.

cards.name: Vivid Grove
cards.text:
Vivid Grove enters the battlefield tapped with two charge counters on it.
{T}: Add {G}.
{T}, Remove a charge counter from Vivid Grove: Add one mana of any color.
